The clearest and simplest explanation I have seen as to why the solar system is flat is the one given by Walter Russel. All mass accumulates through the action of a vortex. A vortex has the shape of two opposing cones that meet at a point. Perpendicular to this center of mass accumulation lies the ecliptic. In our case, the center of mass which birthed the planets is our sun. That sun has an equatorial plane in line with the ecliptic. All planets in the solar system began their journey being spun out along this equatorial plane. The sun itself is in motion perpendicular to the plane of the ecliptic so while the system appears flat from our point of view it would be more accurate to consider the motion of the planets a spiral in space time. According to Russel, all direction is curved and all motion is spiral. These are universal laws which he layed out in great detail in “The Universal One” (published in 1927).

Galaxies are relatively flat, it's a global name for a bunch of stuff seen from a certain distance - planets, stars, nebulas, cosmic dust and lots of other junk floating in space together. They do form something, that we call galaxies, because they all float relatively the same way (well they do float in different directions, but still inside boundaries). That overall movement (circling around) shapes it all into a disc, that we see with a telescope.
But I doubt this can apply to a solar system. Are all the planets really aligned in a perfect straight line towards each other? I really doubt that. To extend what he said about 4 dimensions: in an even number of dimensions it works out that the cloud can keep all the dimensions, but in an odd number of dimensions it will lose one dimension. So in 5D space you get 4D solar systems, etc.

The original cloud that the solar system comes from began to spin perhaps because a supernova blew it into a rotational motion. Near the plane of the ecliptic, the gravitational centripetal force was just right in correspondence with the perpendicular inertial velocity for the dust and gas to have circular orbital motion. Further away from this plane, the gravitational centripetal force from the center of mass is not in the plane of the circular motion of the gas and dust. Thus, they experience a weaker component force of the gravitational force as their centripetal force. In relation to their inertial orbital velocity, they can not have circular motion and thus must leave the solar system. Even further up north and south of the center of mass, the gas and dust doesn’t spin. They simply fall into the center.

Ut's not correct to say that there would be "no up and down direction by which particles lose energy by collisions" in 4D space, represents a failure to take into account that every 4D space contains 3D space in the same sense that every 3D space contains 2D space. Just as you noted that if a forming solar system is already rotating around a single axis in 3D space, the rotation space is already "flat" , likewise, for any given set of items orbiting something in 4D hyperspace, it is possible that they are already rotating around a common 2D plane, which would make their rotation space already flat. Yes, it's also possible for that plane they are rotating around to ALSO have things rotating within in, around the other 2D plane of rotation. However, if we're talking about getting to that stage from random orbital paths, consider that for any ser of objects orbiting around a 4D object in 4D space, it is POSSIBLE that those orbital paths all occupy the same 3D hyperplane of that 4D space, and that within such a 3D hyperplane of rotation space they have a net rotation around one axis of that hyperplane. That axis would be your "up and down" as you called it, and could cancel out in the same way leaving a 2D plane of rotation for that set of objects. If, on the other hand, a set of objects were in orbital paths which stuck out of such a shared 3D hyperplane just a little, but still managed to cancel the movement in one of those three directions in that same way, what would remain of the orbital paths in 4D space would fit into the remaining 3 dimensions which had not been canceled out. Repeat (or continue) the process to cancel out one more dimension of orbital space and you would be left with a 2D orbital plane around a complementary 2D plane.

It is true that two orthogonal rotation can exist in 4 dimensions, but that doesn’t mean that all movement in 4D necessarily occurs as two such orthogonal rotations. 

If, for example, you were to view time as the fourth dimension (Feasible even given its hyperbolic topology if you stay within the lightcone), a circling cloud of dust ⟨sin(t), cos(t), 0⟩, which would be a helix, would still bump into a rock oscillating up and down ( z = sin(t) ). So you could see conservation of angular momentum at work on the curl components of the trajectories in the 3 spatial dimensions. 

As for spherical globularity in 4D, if you look at Feynman diagrams of antiparticles, they look (mathematically) exactly like particles going backwards in time, and while we’re still not sure what that means, it both allows for sphericallness in 4D and the observed disk-ness in 3D.

O.K so from what I gather, from this video and the comments, when millions/etc'illions of particles go random directions in many random orbits in space, some orbits cancel other orbits until eventually there is a common spin.

While this is all happening, the manifested common spin means that the centrifugal force dissipates above and below the common spin.

Since the centrifugal force above and below becomes weaker, the gravity above and below is stronger, pulling the lingering particles towards the nearest clump of particles (Planets).

I challenge your assertions regarding 4 dimensional space.  Collisions could indeed happen in 4 dimensional space, but the idea that gravity would necessarily work in 4 dimensions within 4 dimensional space seems like an unsupported assertion.  If gravity as a force were to still only operate within 3 dimensions then you'd have all the objects within those 3 dimensions again on a plane, but within the 4th dimension they could be scattered (and in fact likely would as the collisions that would occur would tend to scatter them).  This is all of course based on the notion that space really is 3 dimensions to begin with, which is itself a bit of an assertion at this point.  We can after all represent any point in space with but a single coordinate if desired (this system is not used because it is vastly inferior to using 3 coordinates for practical purposes... perhaps all practical purposes).

Does it have nothing to do with moving gravity wells aligning to form the most energy-efficient paths of motion?  E.g. doesn't the material in Saturn's rings form a denser gravitational field than if the rings weren't there; so any given rock within the rings would stay within the area of the rings because the rings have their own gravitation that favor motion remaining within that area?

By the same logic there would be less gravitation outside the plane of the solar system because of all the dispersed matter within the plane increasing the gravitation of the plane itself.  Presumably if a probe was launched from Earth to Jupiter using a trajectory that arcs over the sun and the asteroids, more energy would be required than if the same probe is sent along a trajectory through or near the asteroids.  

It seems there would be something like a dispersed gravity-assist effect within the plane that would be absent outside of it.  Still, the video makes a good point that any motion that would be occurring outside the plane would be more likely to cancel out because of the lack of common systemic rotation.

Small correction man, clouds of dust don't initially clump together because of gravity, but because of static electricity. The dust particles colliding with each other create electric charges which cause them to stick together in groups. As more dust is affected by this, the clumps become more massive, eventually gaining a strong enough gravitational pull that it takes over the static-electric effect. The astronaut Donald Pettit discovered this by shaking a bag of salt while he was in space. Boom! Science!

I thought it was  a flat disk because its a rotating body with a central gravitational mass, and by the laws of our universe any rotating body produces a "flat plane" normal to the center of the rotating axis. Even without the collisions that cancel momentum, the gravitational force of the primary rotating body should still produce a fairly flat plane of whatever rotating debris were around it, right? I mean, given enough time of course. It seems logical to assume the debris above the poles would not be rotating fast enough to defy the gravitational pull of the primary body, effectively "clearing" those areas by gravity alone as those particles would eventually collide with the primary gravitational body. The debris between the polar areas and the "flat plane" would move slowly toward the center of the primary body, but as they draw closer to the body they approach the galactic plane, and since the plane of a rotating sphere moves faster, the debris would naturally accelerate about the primary body in the rotational direction, eventually to the point that they are falling around the rotating body at an equal or faster rate than the gravitational force toward it [i.e. orbital velocity]. Thus, without collisions, the debris would pass the "galactic plane" and the gravitational pull of the central body would begin acting against its velocity in the direction away from the galactic plane, causing it to slowly curve back towards the galactic plane, and would continue to oscillate in this manner until it reached an equilibrium [i.e. a flat disk about the rotating axis]. Is my thinking flawed here? Granted, collisions do speed up the process immeasurably, but it just doesn't seem logically necessary to have collisions in order to create a flat disk about a star, though it would be necessary for the creation of planets. My point being that rotation [spin] and gravity would be the primary cause of a flat solar system in our universe, and collisions are more akin to the cause of planetary bodies within that solar system, but it would still be flat either way.

The principle seems to be that a random grouping in n-dimensional space will end up 'flattening' to a n-1 dimensional grouping within that space.

If n=3, then the resulting shape is a disc, with the objects sharing a similar value for the 3rd axis.

if n=4, the resulting shape will be a sphere, and the objects will end up having similar values for the 4th axis.

Basically, over time a spinning collection of objects will end up utilizing one less dimension than there is available.

Is that correct? I think that's what is implied by the bit of 4D at the end, but the narrator doesn't specifically state this.

Also, the very concept of 'spinning' doesn't work very well in 4 dimensions, but I doubt we gain more insight by trying to visualize that.

Now here's a question; would a 4-D cloud collapse into a 3-D "disk" (I guess a sphere?) for the same reasons?

Here are the problems with this:
1) The video assumes that a gravitational center to gas clouds in space would bring the gas and dust together into the sun and planets. However, the gravitational force in the middle of the gas and dust cloud that would bring the whole thing together would bring it all together into a single body, rather than a star, 8 planets and dozens of moons.
2) Boyle's gas law would prevent the gasses in the center from forming into a star because as it is compressed by gravity, the gasses would be repelled from each other because there is no outside pressure to hold it together (this is why balloons expand and eventually pop as they gain altitude).
3) He also said that as stuff hits each other in the cloud, particles would eventually all have the spin that the cloud originally had as a whole. However, Venus, Neptune and Pluto are all rotating in a manner different from all of the other planets, Jupiter, Uranus and Neptune all have moons going in both directions around the planets, and the Sun, which has 98% of the mass in the solar system, only has 2% of the angular momentum.
While the video was made very well (and I personally found it very interesting), there are just a few physics problems involved with what he said happened.

So this is basically what I understood from this video. I'm an 18 year old non-physics student so please correct me if I'm wrong :)

At the start, he gave 2 reasons for the Solar System being flat: 1) collision between particles and 2) having 3 spacial dimensions.

For the first reason,
1:15 Total angular momentum is like the rough average direction in which the particles are moving. Like in a hurricane, every particle has it's own path of movement, but as a whole the hurricane looks like it's spinning in 1 direction. Now in the case of the Solar System, it's much more messy.
1:41 Particles lose kinetic energy when they bump into each other.
1:52 Conservation of angular momentum is like what he said, the spinning as a whole does not stop.
So the particles still continue orbiting the Sun while they lose the energy that allows them to pull away from the gravity of the Sun. Thus, they end up only spinning with the main up of down movement being their movement closer to the 'equator' of the spinning mass due to the Sun's gravity, hence the flattening effect.

For the second reason,
2:05 about the four spacial dimensions, he's explaining that in the three dimensional model that was just explained, the particles in the xyz-space have only the choice to move into the xy-plane (as explained at 1:33 ). However with the new w-axis, the particles can move in the wz-plane, which is not affected by the xy-plane, so particles would be able to move between planes and thus remain non-flat, so only a 3 dimensional universe would allow this phenomenon.

Hope this helps in the understanding of this video!

This could have been explained much more easily with the spinning skater on ice / pulling arms in to speed up example. As particles get attracted closer to the center of the cloud due to gravity, the entire cloud speeds up its rotation (whatever bit it started with) to keep angular momentum constant. The same way that a spinning skater pulls her arms to speed up her rotation, and vice versa. This gives a lot of the particles enough speed to form orbits (due to the centrifugal force) around the massive center. Particles at the top and the bottom of the disc just don't have enough speed to keep an orbit so they eventually fall into the massive center or when they move down towards the plane they gain speed again and may form a longer orbit.

This is not entirely true.  All of the planets, dwarfs and asteroids revolve around the sun in one plane except for at least one that I know of.  That one is Pluto (once considered a planet, now considered a dwarf planet).  It's orbit does not follow the ecliptic like all the others do.  And it's a good thing, too, because sometimes it is the "planet" farthest from the sun and sometimes it is not.  That means that if its orbit also followed the ecliptic, at some time or other during the past billion years or so, it would have collided with Neptune.

To summarize the long winded stuff below, I'm going to ask if it is correct that:
1) this is about orbits
2) orbits are basically oriented to a plane
3) the x and y components define the whole plane
4) the z component defines the orientation of the plane
5) (x and y) perfectly balance each other
6) z has to balance out between (x and y)
7) this is like a spinning disc with a wobble
8) the spinning part is (x and y), the wobble up and down is (z)
9) the wobble becomes less and less as (z) cancels itself out, and transfers its components magnitude over to (x and y)

10) in a 2d world a plane still exists, but can never be oriented differently

--------
the rest of this my initial way of seeing this model, but is very badly written
--------

Perhaps this is incorrect or oversimplified : describing the solar systems as mere  objects orbiting each other, ignoring all the other factors.

If just one planet and the sun was taken into account (to make it simpler),  the planet is orbiting the sun, as well as the sun is orbiting the planet back. It appears one is doing all the orbiting, but it just because the suns movement is negligible, but still being affected.

And if it was simplified even further into 2 equally sized objects orbiting each other.  Then after observing many complete revolutions, it would appear the two objects adhere to an imaginary plane while going around each other in this balance.

If this was just a fictional a two-dimensional world, the plane could not be tilted to any other orientation - it would always have to lie "flat". (To clarify my poor descriptive skills with an visual example) this could be like seeing a large coin glued flat on a horizontal table. One could not pick up a certain end to make it higher than the other. Its not possible to tilt the coin at all.

In a three-dimensional world, a coin could be tilted (a 3rd component - z would be needed to describe the plane with a tilt). In other words, by altering the value of z on one side and applying the equal but opposite amount on the other, the plane will end up being tilted a little more to the one side.

The orbit path - as an imaginary circular path, could be described as the circumference or edge of some imaginary coin. If this tilt was constantly changing (z values), it would be sort of along the surface of a sphere. (but this could be wrong as the coin could be moving). i.e. seeing it as just a 2D disc (the plane is the orientation) that is intersecting a 3D sphere at a point in time - and the edge - the circumference or surface area is the potential position at some point in time.

 -- But the system between the 2 orbiting object works because one object loses the exact opposite velocity that the other gains, and vice versa.
So if this system was visualized as x and y go back and forth in complete balance with each other, on this imaginary plane, the z component affecting the tilt of the plane. (It still makes the circle path become the surface area of the sphere in the bigger picture, but is just describing the same thing in a different way -- as TEAM  x-y  vs TEAM z ). Since x and y balance each other out, z is left to to balance out between the two of them. The result is like seeing the disc more or less coming to a certain orientation of its tilt while having a wobble

please revise to not include comets and smaller bodies.  they are usually inclined to the planetary plane - ISON was 63.4 degrees inclined.  So while the majority of the mass orbiting the sun is within a 7 degree average plane, there are many things still not adhering to the plane, thus making the solar system not flat.  Pluto is inclined 17 degrees, Mercury is 7 degrees.  While both of them are minuscule in terms off percentage of mass when compared to the solar system as a whole, they are not flat to this plane.

Your statement that the solar system started from a nebulous gas, has no scientific basis at all. It is a myth created by Emanuel Swedenborg in 1734 and used by Kant in his General a Theory of Nature in 1775. Swedenborg was a mining engineer with no science background and claimed to be psychic. Laplace endorsed the theory without checking the math, as it clearly could not happen that way. The sun contains 99.86% of the solar systems mass, yet only contains 1.9% of the angular momentum. Also, the larger planets are farther from the sun instead of closer as they should be. Then there are three "pairs" of planets that have almost the exact same spin axis. You can't support a solar origin theory by a long shot. Great Chanel, but don't keep spreading BS elementary textbook science ;)

@gaysquib That's actually a really good question. Keep in mind that every object which has mass participates in gravity, both as being attracted and doing the attracting. The cloud core of interstellar molecular clouds does indeed have mass, which is usually around 10 to the 4 solar masses in the form of gas and dust. Molecular clouds are not just one spherical body so it doesn't have just one gravitational field. The molecular cores are extremely dense, far denser than the outer clouds and thus they collapse under their own weight/gravity. When the molecular cores collapse, they fragment into clumps around 0.1 parsecs in size and 10 to 50 solar masses in mass. Once a clump has broken free from the other parts of the cloud core, it has its own unique gravity and identity and thus a protostar is born.

Great video.  As I understand it while a 4D galaxy wouldn't be '2D flat' it would be '3D flat.' Let me explain: To us, the image of a shadow on a wall is '2D flat', but if we existed in 4 spacial dimensions as 4D people, then a shadow of us would be 3D, and I'd think that that would seem 'flat' to a 4D person.  So while a 4D galaxy wouldn't be 2(ish) dimensionally flat, it might be considered 'flat' from a 4D perspective even tho it is 3D.  Another way to think about this is what would 'flat' look like to a 2D person?  I'm guessing it would be something 1D, like a line. lol, for people who are confused about atoms, electrons are not all equally spaced away from the nucleus, they work in orbitals due to shield and what not, and even then they don't technically orbit perfectly around the nucleus, there's just a probability around the nucleus where it could be.
